answers.answer: Autoimmune diseases almost always are extraordinary, and often inexplicable.  They also are closely associated with hepatitis c, so you should definitely be checked for that.  (In my opinion, everybody should be checked for hep c, but they're not.) Most of the people on this forum have hep c, but I've seen some posts by folks who have your variety as well as hcvv, though I don't know if they're currently using the forum.  I have a form of scleroderma, and there have been some folks with lupus, thyroid burnout, as well as a lot of diabetes and psoriasis.  I would definitely see a hepatologist and a rheumatologist as well.
Although a hematologist (blood doc) would be a good idea too, a good hepatologist (liver specialist) would be a good choice.
I guess this is the thrust of my question. Also, it's extraordinary that Auto Immune Hepatitis is eight times more common in women.Thanks for your responses. I appreciate them greatly!

Hi Richard,I don’t know much about AIH, other than the little I’ve picked up from others in this forum. Our immune system involves some amazing dynamics; the thought of something this powerful turning against us frankly scares the cr@p out of me. There have been several people here previously that have been diagnosed with AIH, and have recommended the Autoimmune Hepatitis Support Group, UK. Here’s the address: http://www.autoimmunehepatitis.co.uk/aih/I understand that this site has undergone some changes, including possible change of ownership; try it and see if you get a better response to your questions. As mentioned above, the vast majority of us here are dealing with Hep C; we just don’t have the knowledge base to offer much advice. Sorry to hear of your diagnosis, my friend- if you get a chance, let us know if the UK site helps so we can refer others if necessary.Happy journeys, and take care-Bill
